title-group.article-title: Judaism against Paganism: Emmanuel Levinas's Response to Heidegger and Nazism in the 1930s

he said, "It is always with embarrassment that I avow my admiration for this philosopher. It is known what Heidegger was in 1933, even if it was for a short period and even if his disciples, among whom there are many estimable men, forget it. To me it is unforgettable. One can have been anything, except a Nazi."

Bataille put it, "Lévinas, who introduces (without attempting to justify it) the identification of the Nietzschean attitude with the racist attitude, in fact limits himself to providing (without having attempted it) a striking demon- stration of their incompatibility and even of their nature as opposites."
